Well, it works, but it assumes US/AU locale (. for decimals - , for thousands ) so not ideal for multilingual.

klonos said:

not ideal for multilingual.

If you can avoid the thousand separator in general, do so (means: no separator at all). The decimal separator... hm, ... sticking with integers is probably not an option.

I generally agree, but if people are to be building multilingual sites like e-commerce on Backdrop, I'd imagine that they'd need a reliable way to be presenting currency etc in localized decimal/thousand separators.

I seem to recall that localized dates, currencies, and general numbers were never adequately addressed (or even addressed at all) for D7. I spent some time researching it a few years ago, and all I came up with were a few contrib modules and 3rd party libraries that attempted to address it in different ways, but were still incomplete solutions.

Personally, I do think that D and B do a rather good job re localized dates (and sometimes numbers). When it comes to currency and when localized number formats are a must, the air gets thin in general.
That's a playground for accounting software. Even worse if rounding errors are unacceptable. (I already mentioned that I didn't need fully localized number formats so far and that I consider myself lucky.)

Re: https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/4894

I started posting in the Issue, but decided to get feedback first.

I messed with i18n one time and that was on Drupal. That's my experience, so keep that in mind.

I keep seeing translation stuff come up here and there and the idea came to me to have core use hard coded placeholders for all language text, then have a language pack that uses those placeholders.

Any time core needs updated text, descriptions, labels etc, they could live in the language pack file and be applied separately from core releases. No more core PR against text change issues. It also means that someone who is annoyed by core descriptions, labels etc, could create their own language pack and easily override the core pack. The translation module can handle the facilitation of switching between language packs.

I don't know if this is what you're thinking @indigoxela

Language packs could also be added to the install profile as a download (english provided by default?) This way anyone who wants to use Backdrop in a different language, has it ready to go out of the box.

Add a localization concept for user-provided strings to core · Issue #4894 · backdrop/backdrop-issues
Backdrop core ships with content translation, which is fine for sites, that really only need content translation. Additionally there's config translation, which allows to translate certain user...

I keep seeing translation stuff come up here and there and the idea came to me to have core use hard coded placeholders for all language text, then have a language pack that uses those placeholders.
